urn:contentItem:5S65-MST1-F021-64XS-00000-00Aviva hits back at Opperman's claims industry needs to innovate2018-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:00ZLexisNexisPENSIONSVersion:1Aviva hits back at Opperman's claims industry needs to innovateCarmen Reichman

Insurer Aviva has praised the retirement industry for its continued efforts to innovate, saying providers need to take more pride in what they have achieved.

Speaking at the Association of British Insurers (ABI) conference in London today (26 April) Aviva's head of savings and retirement, Alistair McQueen, said there have been a number of big innovations in the marketplace, such as automatic enrolment and pension freedoms so the industry had no reason to be apologetic about not innovating enough.

Despite this, he said Aviva was acutely aware of pressure from the outside from the likes of big tech firms and start ups, and was gearing up for its next innovation drive as a means of 'self preservation'.

The retirement industry has been criticised by the regulator for not innovating enough following the pension reforms and earlier today, Guy Opperman, parliamentary under-secretary of state at the Department for Work & Pensions, reiterated a call for more new products to be developed.

But Mr McQueen said: "I have a clear conscience about my company and our industry in terms of innovation.

"It has been six years since the idea of automatic enrolment was born. Our industry has brought it to nine million people - that is innovation.

"Before we talk about where the next innovation is coming from as an industry we need to change our mindset.

"We are not apologetic, we are not slow, we are demonstrating innovation despite Brexit, governance committees, charge caps, Solvency II, Mifid, the Financial Advice Market Review and the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

"Despite all of that we have done magnificent amounts of change."

Aviva has set up an innovation hub called digital garage, which is working with technology firms, philosophers and others to bring a "fresh perspective" to the market.

Mr McQueen said the reality was there were more people retiring in the next 10 years with more money than there have ever been before.

At the same time he said the industry largely fails to engage with them.

He said: "We believe, and to some extent we fear, this industry is ripe for that word disruption.

"If you are a disrupter with some big pockets this is a market that is incredibly rich for disruption.

"Aviva feels that fear and and therefore we are challenging ourselves to disrupt ourselves first before somebody else comes along and does it.

"It is our mode of self-preservation and simplification - thinking outside the box is a key part there."

Aviva will be piloting a midlife MOT next month in Norwich to judge whether there is any value in the proposition.

The idea of a midlife MOT was called for by the ABI in its report out today and this concept was also backed by Mr Opperman.

Aviva launched its project on Tuesday (24 April) and within 24 hours 50 per cent of the seats available had been taken, Mr McQueen said.

He said: "There is a demand to get support and get service because people understand the importance of this and there is a huge price for the provider who can come into this market and do that."

But he acknowledged regulation was still hampering innovation and efforts to create better consumer engagement.

He said customers want simplicity and transparency and the regulator was more on the transparency side.

"It is very difficult to deliver simple communications at the same time as delivering transparent communications because transparency brings with it caveats, footnotes, qualification and sub-clauses.

"I fear we have gone too much into the detail of transparency to the detriment of simplicity."

Craig Fazzini-Jones, chief executive of Retirement Advantage, shared this view.

He also said innovation was not spurred by consumer demand but by regulatory change.

Mr Fazzini-Jones said: "If we had sat in the room before (former chancellor George) Osborne announced the (pension freedom) changes we probably wouldn't have launched the [retirement account] because we wouldn't have thought the market was ready for it."

Before the Retail Distribution Review (RDR) the market was black and white, people either went for annuities or drawdown, he said.

But the rules that came after the pension reforms meant people could actually house an annuity inside drawdown and that gave them a lot of benefits in terms of tax planning and control, he said.

Mr Fazzini-Jones said: "Strangely enough the advent of the reforms in a way is what drove the innovation because we had to respond to a market that didn't want to buy annuities anymore and to think more about customer needs.

"By offering the retirement account we gave the advisers something to talk about to their customers to the effect of what they were hoping to get: have a guarantee, more flexibility, more control."

VINCE KEENAN, VP, DIRECTOR IR, AVNET: Okay. Good morning, and welcome to Avnet's 2006 Analyst Day from New York City. I am Vince Keenan, Vice President and Director of Investor Relations for Avnet. As you can see on this slide, we have a very full agenda today. Over the course of the morning, we will provide an overview of Avnet's strategy and value proposition, as well and update on our financial performance and business model.

In an effort to better convey the value we bring into technology supply chain, we have added a customer panel this year to both of our operating groups, Electronics Marketing and Technology Solutions. We are confident that our customers' participation will add additional insight into the vital way that Avnet plays in an increasingly complex supply chain.

I'd just like to cover, right now, a few housekeeping items. We will Q&A sessions throughout the day. And I would appreciate if you could all wait until a microphone is brought over to you. And then, you can ask a question. And also, please limit yourself to one question and one follow up.

Also, as you can see, we have a full agenda and only one break at 10:15, so when we do break, I'd appreciate if everybody could get back on time, so we can stay on schedule. And again, at the end of the day, we have a boxed lunch outside. You're welcome to grab a lunch, come back in, and the executive team will be available for discussions or further questions.

Before we get started, if you are listening by webcast today and have not accessed the slides that accompany this presentation, please go to our website, www.ir.avnet.com and click on the icon announcing this event. In addition to disclosing financial results that are determined in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles or GAAP, the company also discusses non-GAAP results of operations that exclude certain items. Reconciliations of the company's to GAAP can be found on Avnet's website and in several of the slides in this presentation.

I would also like to quickly review Avnet's Safe Harbor statement. This presentation contains certain forward-looking statements, which are statements addressing the future financial and operating results of Avnet. Listed on this slide are several factors that could result -- that would cause those numbers to differ materially from those described in the forward-looking statements.

With us today are Roy Vallee, Chairman and CEO; Rick Hamada, Chief Operating Officer, who is also acting President of Technology Solutions; Ray Sadowski, Chief Financial Officer; and Harley Feldberg, President of Electronics Marketing. With that, let's get our day started. And I'd like to introduce you to Roy Vallee, Chairman and CEO.

ROY VALLEE, CHAIRMAN, CEO, AVNET: Okay. Thanks, Vince. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for taking the time to be with us today, very excited about this opportunity and looking forward to a very productive day. So, let me just walk through what my plans are. I'm going to talk to you a little bit about Avnet today, in case there's any newcomers to the story, just give a quick snapshot type of an overview; then going to talk about the industry environment and the trends that we're seeing, and in the process, talk about the opportunities that exist for Avnet to continue to grow its business on a global basis.

I think there's some particularly interesting things happening in the semiconductor cycle, if you will, and I'm going to point to those and draw some attention to them. And I do want to make a disclaimer that it is not my intent to predict the future of the semiconductor cycle, but I would like to make some observations about things that we see going on that you might find interesting. And then, I'm going to talk about Avnet's strategy from the Avnet Inc. perspective.

Rick and Harley, of course, will talk a lot more about the strategy that's being put to work inside of our business units. But, Avnet Inc. has a way of thinking about what we want to do with our company and a framework for that, so I'm going to share that with you as well.

So first of all, Avnet operates within the global technology supply chain at two different points, one where we sell electronic components, literally for the world's leading technology suppliers. And we sell those to essentially anyone who manufactures electronic equipment. And then, in the case of information technology, we pick up again with enterprise class hardware along with software and services, and we resell that, predominantly, through resellers and system builders to deliver those goods to the end users.

Over the past 50 years plus now, we've been growing our business, both organically and through M&A. What we've seen -- what we show you here is that we have a business that ended with $14.25 billion in sales for fiscal year '06, ended last June, and we are increasing operating margins steadily coming off the technology bubble bursting that took place in the early part of this decade.

There's some additional verbiage here about the products and services that each one of our operating groups is involved in. If you drop down to the pie charts at the bottom, as of the end of fiscal year '06, we're giving you a flavor for how the business is composed. About two-thirds of revenues are at Electronics Marketing. As you can see, it's a higher margin business than Technology Solutions, so about 72% of our income is derived from that group.

And on the other hand, it is also the more asset-intensive business unit, so it has a disproportionate share of our assets as well. And you'll throughout the day that, we drive these businesses to the same return on capital employed, and so the lower margins requires a higher velocity at Tech Solutions.

So with that, let me just jump into a macro view of the industry that we are fortunate enough to serve. If we zoom in our Electronics Marketing operating group, we see that the market in the 2006 for electronic components, which we are a franchise for, the markets that we address, it's up over $250 billion. And over the next couple of years, it's projected to grow at an 8% or 9% compound annual growth rate.

And we'd like to draw your attention to the illegible asterisk at the bottom, which says that we exclude microprocessor and DRAMs from this TAM data. This indicates our semiconductor data does not match yours, and the reason is because we don't sell these products at Electronic Marketing for all practical purposes. We move those through Technology Solutions into the system builder marketplace.

One of the key trends, of course, in this business is the growth of Asia Pacific. So, what you can see is that from the early part of this decade, Asia-Pac has sort of pulled away, if you will, and has become by far, the largest region of the world for semiconductor consumption. So, you see the projected five-year compound annual growth rate for Asia to be in the 12% range. Notice though that, while the other three are sort of bunched together, there is positive growth projected for every region of the world for semiconductors, and we see that as an opportunity for our businesses there.

To move over to Technology Solutions, and again what we've done here is, we've taken industry data, profiled or mix adjusted to the products and services, which we are involved in as a company. And it turns out that that market in 2006 is almost $800 billion. And I do, again, want to clarify. This is the total available market on a global basis. So, this is not necessarily the DTAM or the distributor market, and it includes places like Japan, where we have relatively limited coverage today. But, this is the big picture, total available market that we have the opportunity to serve.

So, you'll notice that it's bigger than the components market, but it's compound annual growth rate over the next couple of years is projected to grow at about 6% or 7% CAGR, where the components market was growing at a faster rate.

Similarly, the Asia-Pac region is, in fact, the fastest growth region. You see it down there at 7.9%, but it is not the largest region by any stretch. Europe and America continue to represent the biggest opportunities in absolute dollar terms. I'll also point out that where in the components business, the notion of worldwide global manufacturing has driven a lot of semiconductor consumption in the Asia-Pac, there is a big difference between computers are built and where computers are used. And so, America still remains a healthy market as does Western Europe.

This is a slide that we borrowed from the Global Technology Distribution Council. They went out and commissioned an independent analyst to do a review of leading IT vendor growth rates compared to the growth of the distributors who move those products into the channels. And what you can see here is that, over the last couple of years, and we expect this to extend into this year, the distribution industry in IT is clearly outgrowing their suppliers, meaning that the DTAM, or distributor total available market, is growing at a faster rate than the TAM.

So, if you aggregate this data, the electronics marketing served market, the TS served market, do a stacked bar, what you see is that an interesting milestone has occurred here in 2006, and that is our global total market available to us has crossed over the $1 trillion mark, so that's an interesting number. And when you aggregate the growth rates and you mix or weight-adjust them, it turns out that we have a market that's growing around a 7%, possibly an 8% compound annual growth. So the message here is, we are operating in a large market that is growing at a reasonable rate.

There's another interesting trend here. So, the solid lines indicate the past, what has happened. And what we've done here is overlaid the growth of the IT business, which tends to be economically cyclical against the growth of our semiconductor industry, which tends to be volatile, driven by supply and demand imbalances that occur on a regular basis.

So, what you can see is that historically, there was a lot of volatility. If you take the industry-leading forecasters, and they are referenced there, and you could use pretty much anybody you would like, the expectations going forward are that the components industry, and more specifically semiconductors, are going to grow at a much less volatile rate, a lower overall secular growth rate, but much less volatile.

And our computer business, we expect to continue along with its economic cyclicality, but relatively stable compared to our history with semiconductors. And this could be a whole new environment for Avnet and for the industry to operate in.

So, what I'd like to do now is focus on, what are the structural changes that are occurring in the semiconductor industry and see if we can figure out why those expert forecasters, who get paid a lot of money for predicting the future, are saying that the past is not prologued. So first of all, we have an industry that has grown quite nicely since it's inception, and in fact, worldwide total semiconductors will be around $245 billion this year. That will represent a new record for global consumption of semiconductor products. That's terrific.

Something else we've done here is, we've taken the individual years, and we've looked at the growth rate. And if the rate of growth was greater than 5%, we've indicated that that's a pretty good year and given that a green light, if you will. If the year grew, but it was less than 5%, we gave that a yellow. And if the growth was negative, we gave that a red. So, what you can see is that the bulk of the years are green, but every once in a while, red and yellows pop into the equation.

So, record year for sales, but if you look at the annual growth rates and you plot them, of course the first thing you observe is that we have Coney Island roller coaster going on here. And you also see that the secular trend is for a slower and slower annual growth rate for the semiconductor industry.

However, if you zoom in on just that last five-year period, the five-year compound annual growth rate is now actually re-accelerating. And in fact, it's re-accelerating to a double-digit rate of growth. So, as we lose the '00 to '01 compare, which was a very negative year, -34% as I recall, we now over the last five years, are in a positive growth environment, and in fact interestingly enough, a double-digit growth, 12.4%.

So, what is a normal semiconductor cycle? We're all familiar with the historical volatility. We'd just like to point of things on this chart. For 20 years, roughly '77 to '97, the cycles were five years long. There were four good years and one bad year. It turns out that one cycle was four years, and one cycle was six years, but it seems pretty predictable.

And what you see there is a bunch of green bars with one red, and then a bunch of green bars with one red, and it seemed like we could all time the semiconductor market. And in fact, I think maybe a few of us have made a little money selling on the change in the second derivative and buying back at trough valuations, and then riding the semiconductors up and down.

And then very interesting, we had a two-year cycle and a three-year cycle in a very short period of time. And then, if you look at this chart, the way the dotted lines work is, we just marked the trough of each cycle. So, we could all put a different definition, actually, on what the beginning and end of each cycle is.

But for talking purposes, we've just consistently marked the trough. And of course, the trough in the current cycle is 2001. And so, we have '02, '03, '04, '05. '06 is in the can, and that means if '07 turned out to be a trough year, we would have another six-year cycle tying the industry's longest up-cycle without a red bar. Okay?

But I think, as most of you know, industry analysts are actually forecasting another growth year in 2007, something on the order of 6% or 7% or 8% growth. Some people seem to think it's going to look an awful lot like 2006 by the time the year is through. And beyond that, these same forecasters who are already on record saying that they expect that growth is going to accelerate in 2008. And if those two things do happen, if those two things do happen and '09 turns out to be a trough year, we will have had a nine-year cycle. This is unprecedented territory for global semiconductors.

So, let's drill down now and look at, what are some of the structural changes that are responsible for this change in the industry's environment. And what I'm going to do right now is focus on the demand management and inventory management side of the equation. And in a moment, I'm going to shift over and talk about the supply side. So first of all, I think we all know that the consumer end markets have been growing faster than the traditional industrial-type end markets for semiconductors. And this is a classic X chart. It looks like an X to me. And it just shows that, in the early part of this decade, consumer overtook business and government spending.

So, why is that important? Well, let's think about that traditional industrial spender on semiconductors. That company's operating with equipment gross margins in the 40%, 50%, 60% range with product lifecycles, which span years typically. That's still true today, by the way, for most industrial companies. So, when you shift over to the consumer OEMs, the gross margins are in the teens, maybe the low 20s, and the product lifecycles are measured, literally, in months, two, three, four months, somewhat depending upon what the competition does.

And so, if you're managing inventory and you're in that industrial environment, the name of the game was, don't run out of parts. If you're in the consumer business, the name of the game is, don't get stuck with parts. The prices are dropping. The margins are thin to start with, and the product may ultimately be obsolete, requiring an inventory write-down altogether. So my observation is, I believe that the consumer demand part of the semiconductor industry will be better at managing inventory than the traditional industrial sector, and it's simply the necessity being the mother of invention.

Another thing that's happening is, in the world equipment market, electronic equipment, the OEMs, the traditional buyers of semiconductors, have been outsourcing at a very high rate. And according to this data, in 2006, about 35% of the world's electronic equipment was produced by a third-party service provider, and EMS or ODM company. And we group these because it's getting more and more difficult to separate the two.

And so now, let's look at the business model for these companies versus their OEM customers. And I think as you all know, the EMS and ODM community are operating on very narrow margins, in almost all cases, single digits. And yet, they are responsible for carrying the vast majority of the working capital in the supply chain.

So, with necessity being the mother of invention once again, it strikes me that the EMS community is going to focus on inventory management and pay a lot more attention to getting that right from and ROIC perspective than its OEM counterparts, who have a lot more margin and even the ability to sort of control future production by model that the EMS companies just don't have. So again, I feel tight inventory management here relative to the OEM customers. This business model simply requires higher inventory velocity.

And then perhaps a controversial statement, but I'm going to throw it out anyway. And Vince said he gave me Safe Harbor so, there's been a couple of interesting accounting changes. One sort of commonly known as revenue rec and another one as Sarbanes-Oxley and specifically, the 404 provision. And what these two things have done, it used to be in the manufacturing world, and by the way, far beyond the electronics industry. This goes into consumer goods and a variety of industries, but when businesses started to slow, the manufactures would push product out into their channels as a way to sort of manage earnings.

And most of that opportunity has now evaporated as a result of these accounting regulations. And so my observation here is simply that, there is less of an opportunity and less of an incentive for manufacture to push inventory into their channel. As a result of that, generally speaking, inventories should end up a little bit lower.

Wonder, what is the data say? If we look at the impact of more consumer demand, more outsourcing to third-party service providers, accounting regulations and maybe some other factors as well, the data says that the total technology supply chain has reduced the number of days in inventory by a dramatic amount, obviously influenced by the bubble and the burst. Obviously for the last couple of quarters, there's been a tactical change here based on an inventory correction that's taking place. But, if you step back for a minute and look at the structural changes in the supply chain that are leading the secular change, what you see is less days in inventory.

So now, let's shift to the back of the supply chain and look at a couple of things that are happening from a supply perspective. So first of all, pure play foundries, so these are companies like TSMC, UMC and Chartered. Now, these companies are growing at a 23% compound annual growth rate, and I think you all know, that is substantially faster than the overall semiconductor industry and the clients that they serve. So, what this means is that, more and more of the world's silicon wafers are being produced by third-party service providers.

So, what's important about this? Well first of all, in the old days when business was good, all of the semiconductor companies, CI, Motorola, National, Fairchild, seemingly would build factories in about the same timeframe. The capacity would all come on stream, and we would have a supply-induced semiconductor correction. The foundries, now, do not build factories until they have demand from a variety of semiconductor companies, each one of them having their own end-market profiles for the products that they're manufacturing. So, we have a more efficient allocator of this capital than the individual semiconductor companies.

From a semiconductor company's point of view, the difference now is, if CI were running out of capacity in the 90s, it had to consider carefully when to go build that next, and in those days, you would have said billion dollar Fab and today you say 2 to $3 billion Fab, depending on what kind of output they want to [put it to]. Now what they can do is buy more wafers. And they can do that iteratively, and they can increase wafer orders in the March quarter and they can decrease wafer orders in the June quarter. And so what's happening here is, the -- this notion of excess capacity is coming well under control.

And aside from the pure play foundries, we also have semiconductor companies teaming in, essentially, joint venture partnerships. There are a variety of ways these things are configured, but the impact is still the same. Now, you have two or three companies sharing the investment and sharing the output, so it's a more iterative or analog approach to increases in capacity. And oh, by the way, underneath this, there are many semiconductor companies who are operating as a foundry for a specific process technology and a specific set of parts for other semiconductor companies. And all of this tends to happen under the radar screen.

So, these all provide similar benefits to the pure play foundry model, with pure play being the most efficient way to allocate capital in this industry, followed by JV followed, by individual outsourcing agreements. And as a result of this, it's interesting to observe capacity utilization. In the old days, we would go from severe capacity crunches to capacity excesses. So, numbers like below 80% utilization and numbers like, even over 100% you may have heard quoted from time to time in terms of capacity utilization.

And if you look at this chart, again, this is industry data, SIA and WSTS, it says hmmh, semiconductor capacity utilization worldwide seems to be converging at around the 90% level. And this -- it seems like the volatility, since the big tech bubble, has been diminishing. But, I think overall, our approach towards inventory hasn't really changed relative to what's happening in the environment as opposed to what's happening within our business and the value-based management initiative. I've historically -- I would say that we were driven more from an overall net income perspective as a return on capital perspective.

As we move towards driving the business more and more towards return on capital, that required us to be much more efficient within our working capital utilization. As a result of that, we've become significantly more efficient in using inventory within the Electronics Marketing business.

So the goal essentially is, and we don't measure the goal typically from a dollar perspective. We measure the goal within our businesses, basically from an inventory turns perspective. And if business is growing, we're going to invest more money in inventory. That's what we do for a living. The goal within our business is not to drive inventory to zero. If we drove inventory to zero, we'd be out of business. As you heard earlier from -- I think both customers said, one of the things that we're [inaudible] value is asset, asset, asset.

So from our perspective, we need to have the assets. But of course, we have to have the right assets, and that's what we have done over the last few years, dramatically improved our overall asset mix. So, we measure the businesses more from a velocity or inventory turns perspective as opposed to absolute dollars. And Electronics Marketing, as an example, in the most recent few quarters I guess, it goes up and down a little bit, are basically at record levels of inventory turns.

Is there further improvement there? There might be, but we're not going to commit to it at this particular point in time. But I would say, there's probably some bias, a little bit more towards the upside from an inventory, working capital, productivity improvement at EM. But, it probably will not be as dramatic as it was over the last few years or so.

HARLEY FELDBERG: Okay. And I think the second question related to, do we provide regular inventory status to our suppliers, or how many? And the answer would be, essentially, 100% of our suppliers, semiconductor and otherwise get regular feeds and regular updates on our inventory overall. What I would say, editorializing a bit, is what they do with it varies dramatically by supplier.

So, our most progressive suppliers -- and in a way, this an ad -- this is an adjunct to what Ray just said. We're working with a number of our suppliers, and including some of our largest who are very committed to reducing inventory overall in our combined channel, and with those who are working on some real creating things relative to backing up more of the dollars further into unfinished space. That requires a shared investment commitment to things like RosettaNet and eBI and all of that.

There are obviously many other suppliers who are less progressive, in those cases we manage a more traditional relationship. But 100% of our suppliers get an inventory fee from us at least monthly.

LOU MISCIOSCIA: Hi, Ray, Lou Miscioscia from Cowan & Company. I guess a good lead in to my question which is return on capital, maybe if you could start off and give us what you actually are putting your WACC at these days? And if you could also define capital? And then --.

RAY SADOWSKI: I'm sorry, I couldn't hear you, could you say that one more time?

LOU MISCIOSCIA: Sure. Could you give us what your WACC is? Weighted average cost of capital? And then obviously how you're defining capital in your return on capital equation? Are you putting goodwill into it? And then I have a follow-up.

RAY SADOWSKI: Sure okay. If I ask ten people what our weighted average cost of capital is, I think you know the answer, I'll get ten different answers.

LOU MISCIOSCIA: I'll take the average then.

RAY SADOWSKI: Alright and I see numbers as low as in the low 9s up to one what I thought was a ridiculous number, almost 13%. So essentially the way we manage our business, we cut through all that and say our weighted average cost of capital is 10%. It's based upon all those things considered, I won't say that's an exact average, but it's close enough where that's roughly what the overall average weighted cost of capital is.

In terms of where are we including capital, we essentially include everything. So if you look at it from the right hand side of the balance sheet it's total interest bearing debt plus equity, so it would include, as my colleagues over here know quite well, it would include goodwill.

LOU MISCIOSCIA: Okay great. Then my really I guess two follow-ups to that would be it looks like you're not taking the options hit and I'm just wondering if there's any view of changing that, given a lot of the big OEMs are actually including options expense obviously in their number?

RAY SADOWSKI: No we are including option expense in the number.

LOU MISCIOSCIA: You are, okay.

RAY SADOWSKI: If you look back, it depends -- well if the numbers I just presented, hopefully if we did them right they should include option expensing. If you were to look at numbers a year ago we would not have included option expensing mainly because fiscal '06 was our first year having option expensing and we wanted to make sure we were comparing it apples-to-apples with the prior periods of time. But on a go-forward basis anything that we're presenting will at all times include option expensing. We won't point out what the number is, just so people can understand that, but our numbers do include options expensing.

LOU MISCIOSCIA: Okay so the 12.5 includes that?

RAY SADOWSKI: Yes it does.

LOU MISCIOSCIA: Okay thank you.

RAY SADOWSKI: And that's a good point because now you reminded me, I said three things impacted, [as far as weighting] correctly, three things impacted overall some of our change to our model, the two biggest ones being EM Asia growth and the second one being Access, the third one not a big impact but still an impact, roughly 10 basis points of return on capital, is the fact that in last year's business model --.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Operating margin.

RAY SADOWSKI: Operating margin --.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: [inaudible - microphone inaccessible] 10 basis points on operating margin.

RAY SADOWSKI: But it's also the same in return on capital, roughly.

UNIDENTIFIED COMPANY REPRESENTATIVE: Okay.

RAY SADOWSKI: Roughly. Roughly a little more than that, but it's roughly the same. So operating margin is about 10% return on capital, a little bit more than that, and so that's 10 basis points. That's roughly what we factored in so that's another reason why we basically changed our overall operating income margin down a little bit. So that is included in all of our numbers now.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: I wanted to ask the top-line question a little bit different way, what sort of revenue growth do you need to hit your long-term margin target and your long-term return on capital target? And then from a cost side, what sort of flexibility do you have if revenue comes in below that?

RAY SADOWSKI: Okay. I guess baked into our model overall is roughly in the 7 to 8% overall top-line growth. And in terms of from an expense perspective, it's an interesting question which we obviously get quite a bit. As we've mentioned a couple times today, the biggest piece of our expenses people is 70% of our people and the way we look at our business is, if we knew absolutely what was going to happen to the business over the next 12 months we could take certain actions today in order to streamline the business.

However one of the things that you need to keep in mind, and I think Roy touched upon this earlier today, there is a significant amount of cost associated with changing the expense model in business up and down. And so we've made appropriate changes over the last few years with significant reductions in expenses because we basically saw an overall change in the business on a long-term perspective.

If we saw or we felt that we'd have a continual decline in business, then we would take the appropriate actions necessary to basically hit these targets. It might make it a little bit more difficult obviously, but the goal is to get these targets through a cycle. Our expectation, as you've heard quite a bit today, is that the cycles will not be as high or as low as they used to be, so therefore we're not expecting to be put in a position of taking wholesale expense action.

But if we're proven wrong, then we'll do the things that are appropriate to deliver shareholder value as rapidly as possibly we can. And I think we've demonstrated that previously through some of the expense actions we've taken back in the 2002 time frame when the bubble burst.

JIM SUVA: Thanks Ray, Jim Suva here from Citigroup. If I look about the GE Access integration and seeing that it represents about 14% roughly of your company, is it fair to say you guys will probably take a little bit of time to digest and integrate this acquisition and therefore put future acquisitions a little bit on the back burner for a few quarters? Or is there still room to digest some more?

RAY SADOWSKI: Well interesting question, one of the things we've found, we've done a lot of acquisitions as you well know, and one of the most important things in any acquisition is speed of integration. And this is a sizeable acquisition and a lot of people currently working, spending a lot of time preparing for the acquisition that again we mentioned should close hopefully December 31.

But our expectation at this particular point in time, although I won't say plans are final yet, but our expectation is the business from a system and a whole host of other ways of measuring it will be completed integrated by the end of June. There are certainly other things that impact integrated people, getting them to know and understand the Avnet culture and the way we do things, it takes a little bit longer, but in terms of just initial integration of systems and processes and things like that, that ought to be completed by the end of June.

In terms of what does that mean for future acquisitions, interesting question again. That depends upon what the opportunities are. It's safe to say that with the Access acquisition Rick and his team are not actively looking for, at least in the Americas and Europe, what can I acquire. Are they actively looking in Asia? The answer is absolutely yes. So if the right opportunity came along, met our return on capital targets, I'm not sure that we would shy away from it, we certainly would think twice about it. If it were in technologies in the Americas, but if it were in electronic marketing we'd look at it from a return perspective and we would probably move forward.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Hey Ray, a question for you on cash from operations. What would you expect to generate maybe in the December quarter and then also in the March quarter? Do you expect to generate cash, or use cash just from operations?

RAY SADOWSKI: You know interesting, one of the numbers I just had run recently and you may say I should have had this number in my back pocket a long time ago but for whatever reason didn't, wanted me to calculate. But based upon our size of working capital, if our days are impacted by one day, it's roughly $150 million of cash.

And so one of the reasons why we tend to hesitate relative to giving specific guidance on cash flow is, depending upon what happens towards the end of a month, we could easily use $100 million. In this particular quarter it is much more difficult mainly because of the Technology Solutions business, as you heard earlier, the percentage of business that gets done in the last couple weeks of December makes it difficult to predict what kind of situation we're going to be in.

But I will say overall, with our expected reduction in inventory and electronics marketing and all other things being equal from a receivable generation and payable generation of the business, that we would generate cash in the December quarter. I'm not going to give a number, but our expectation is that it would be positive and at this particular point in time I don't see any reason why it would not be positive in the March quarter as well.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Okay. Is there any way maybe for calendar 2007, is there any way you could just quantify how much cash you think you could generate then, given a demand environment of basically pretty stable say 2.5% GDP growth?

RAY SADOWSKI: I guess the way I would look at it now is say that, if you look at calendar year '07 that if we see modest growth in business, that we'd see certainly growth in dollars from a working capital perspective. So again it would be positive, but I'd have to sit and do some math before I gave you an answer to the question because somehow I'd get held accountable for doling a number.

ROY VALLEE: Let me just help a little bit with the math. So we have been under spending on CapEx relative to depreciation rates since the bubble, but those lines are now intercepted. So from my perspective, I would think about CapEx and depreciation just at about neutral. So then if you take your model and run a top-line growth number, you know pick you number, 6 7%, whatever you think the right top line is, and then assume that working capital velocity is the same or maybe slightly better than current levels.

By the time we get out of this quarter we think working capital will be about -- the velocity will rise in the March quarter at EM anyway, but assume that working capital for sales is roughly flat and then compare that to net income, you know subtract that from net income, and round numbers you'll get there. So pick your own top-line number, make an assumption about working capital of sales, let CapEx and depreciation offset each other and you should be able to come up with a close estimate of cash flow.

And to Ray's point, any given quarter with the working capital so large and the net income relatively small, our quarterly period could be volatile, but our [low lean] four quarter period or an annual period should be a lot more in line with that overall model.

RAY SADOWSKI: Okay. Alright I'll turn it back over to Roy who will close it out.

ROY VALLEE: Okay thanks Ray. Before I jump into my summary, I would like to take this opportunity to offer a special thanks to the panelists first of all for taking the time to be here in New York City, and of course all the kind words that you said about Avnet, but also for all of your business. These are terrific customers of ours, they were invited here after we screened customers for what their comments were going to be. That's actually not true.

They were actually invited here because they represent a cross section of the types of engagements we have with a variety of customers, our Tier 2 EMS, Tier 1.5 EMS, an OEM customer, an IBM VAR, a Storage VAR, a Hewlett Packard VAR, so we wanted to give you that sort of a cross section. So thanks again to those folks.

Okay so this is actually going to be brief, we're down to the home stretch unless you want to ask some more questions at the end. We've talked a little bit about this already, Avnet's value creation Arrow. I think that the point I would make is that Ray has now summarized the financials over the last several years and even more specifically over the last year or two, and I think that you can see the financials are demonstrating that we are moving into a value creation era for Avnet.

Harley and Rick then talked about what are we doing from an operating group, from a Chief Operating Officer perspective, to ensure that Avnet's future is as bright as Avnet's past. And we certainly feel that we and hopefully we were able to communicate to you the value we bring to the supply chain and why we feel the way we do. And we look at the role that distribution in general and Avnet in specific is playing in the supply chain today, and we feel very comfortable with our ability to continue to deliver value to our trading partners and in the process create value for our shareholders.

There are some proof points so I just took a snapshot here of the last three years. And the 16% revenue CAGR actually does include M&A, but I thought it was fair in the context of this chart because the EPS includes all the debt and all the equity that was used in that revenue growth as well, and we were able to grow earnings at a substantially faster rate than revenues, despite the fact that some of that came from M&A. And we were able to do this in EPS while deleveraging the balance sheet, as Ray showed you, down to 30% debt-to-capital here as we exited last fiscal year.

And so I'm not predicting that we're going to maintain 100% EPS growth over the next few years, but I think that if you can compare the ratio of EPS growth to earnings, if you can consider the fact that during this three-year period there was a so-called mid-cycle correction that followed the '04 time frame, and these numbers include all of that, I think you can understand why we're pretty excited about the potential we have to grow earnings at a reasonably fast rate over the next few years.

And we've talked a lot over the last few years and specifically this morning about value-based management. We're not just growing revenue, we're not just growing and counting earnings and earnings per share, at the same time we are increasing return on capital employed. And as a result of that, as Ray showed you, that is causing us to increase cash flow generation and of course with that cash we're able to do some exciting things to further augment these results. From our ROCE perspective we remain committed to at least a 12.5% after-tax return on total capital and we believe that we should be able to maybe push up a little bit beyond that, depending on mix of business.

And so, Tom, I think you asked the question what's the capital allocation strategy. Ray did a very good job of stealing my slide but it was okay because I think it's worth just touching on briefly again. You know what's happening here is we have this big market that's growing at a solid but slower secular growth rate. And we have shown you in our model that we have the ability to finance now all of that growth through retained earnings and actually still throw some excess cash off.

So the higher return on capital and the lower secular growth rate is translating into greater levels of cash flow generation than ever before in our company's history. What are we going to do with that cash? Well that's got to be the classic high class problem to deal with. This is sort of a new thing for Avnet. We used to use cash in up cycles and then throw cash in down cycles, and now we're throwing cash in up cycles and if there is a down cycle we're going to throw even more.

So what are we doing? Ray really covered this, you know number one priority is grow the core. The most profitable revenue growth we can fund is our core, but we have a disciplined approach to that that Ray mentioned called drop through, where we want to make ensure that we, to borrow a phrase from BCG, feed the stars and literally starve the dogs. So this is a massive portfolio management exercise.

Beyond that, as Ray said, we have decided strategically that we want to be an investment grade. Those folks that were on the panel, think about can I outsource 100% of my logistics operation to Avnet or can I bet my company's growth on Avnet's ability to finance me and help me as a partner grow and survive in the IT reseller world? And I don't even want them to think about that question.

So Avnet wants to be big and strong and have this balance sheet that is just unquestioned and so we've decided that investment grade ratings are important. We can't control the rating that the agency puts on us, be we certainly can control the statistics that we put up. So our real commitment is a commitment to investment grade statistics, which we believe we currently have.

As a result of that, you'll notice that the Access acquisition was announced as a for-cash deal. And so to the question of buy back, you know if we borrow $400 million and buy back Avnet shares, our coverage and leverage statistics get weakened substantially. If we use that money to acquire the EBITDA that comes with the Access integration, we're able to then actually maintain our commitment to investment grade credit statistics and actually releverage the company, moving debt-to-cap back up into the mid 30s.

And so that's why our bias right now is for M&A as opposed to buy back. However, as you project out, so let's assume for a minute that we're doing all the value creating M&A we can -- and by the way just one minor comment, Jim, to your question about future M&A, you know with our 12.5% hurdle rate for return on capital, it is unusual that we're going to be able to do large transactions. Normally that kind of hurdle rate's going to block those. But I'm laughing because we just did Memec, now we're doing Access and so back-to-back we've had a couple of very unique opportunities to create value for our shareholders.

Going forward with that discipline, which we are hell bent for leather to maintain, it is more likely that we'll do smaller and medium-size transactions, probably acquiring some privately held individuals looking for liquidation strategies as opposed to these big blockbuster type of deals. If they come along and they meet our criteria, by all means we'll move.

They've got to match our culture, they've got to be strategically compatible with where we want to take the company and they've got to meet this return on capital hurdle rate. If they do we'll proceed, if they don't we won't. And sort of tongue-in-cheek, and I hope you take this in the right way and not the wrong way, worst case, we're going to give that cash back to our investors.

If we don't have the opportunity to make value creating M&A investments and fund organic growth with it, then we'll give it back to you and how we give it back is a function of circumstances at the time. What's the stock price? What's the ROI on a buy back? What kind of dividends did we commit to? Is it material? Does it move the needle? And we'll take all those things into consideration.

And I don't think for a moment by the way that M&A and buy backs are mutually exclusive. I think that as time rolls on and we continue to deliver the performance that we think we're going to deliver and our credit statistics maintain at an investment grade level and maybe even go beyond what's needed, then there will be more and more flexibility. The one thing I do know is that our model appears to be generating more cash than ever before in the past and we're going to do our very best to do smart things with that cash to further enhance the value we deliver to our shareholders.

So why should you buy AVT? Well there were a few questions just recently about the top line, look we think components are growing a little faster, computers are growing a little smaller, but we think that we've got a total available market here on a global basis that is now over $1 trillion and growing around 7% a year. If my math is right, that's about $70 billion a year of growth in the products and services that Avnet is currently involved in.

We think there's plenty of room for us to grow and I just would echo what Rick said, we will probably plan to grow slightly faster than the market and we will aspire for double-digit growth. When we build our strategies around that profitable growth pillar in the strategic framework, by operating group, by region, by business unit under the region, we're always asking them, "What are your strategies for double-digit growth?" We don't ask them for their strategies for 7% growth.

Now underneath that TAM what's going on? The distribution industry has proven itself vital. It has for many, many years, it was in question during the bubble, it's reemerged as being absolutely vital to the supply chain and in fact the industry is performing well. And I'd like to point out that, relative to other participants in the supply chain, distribution has an extremely diversified revenue stream. No single supplier concentration, no single customer concentration, this is a well diversified revenue and profit stream.

So now, drilling down on Avnet, hey look I think you'd probably be disappointed if I didn't make this pitch, Avnet is growing globally faster than the market we serve and we're doing that organically and then added the value creating M&A growth to that. So that's the growth story.

We have operating leverage in our model, we are managing the business so as to maintain that operating leverage, and by the way I would tell you that the magic in distribution for earnings growth is around that SG&A and operating income leverage as opposed to -- you know you didn't hear a lot of strategies today about how we're going to raise gross margin by 2 or 3%, that's a very difficult thing for us to do.

We have a lot of effort there to make sure we maintain, slightly grow, slightly decrease, but the real leverage in distribution is the operating leverage around the SG&A and creating value off of that scale that we've talked about so much today.

Now why we're doing that from an earnings point of view, driving our return on capital further into double-digit territory, why 12.5? Because we think in order to be fully valued at our earnings stream we need a return on capital that's 2.5 to 3 points than WACC. As we increase debt as a percentage of total capital we're actually pushing WACC down a bit, our debt capital is a lot less expensive than our equity capital, and so we're going to drive in that 12.5 to 13% range.

We have a strong balance sheet, we will maintain that strong balance sheet as measured by coverage and leverage, we have rising cash flow generation, not just during the down cycle but now through the entire cycle, and I'd like to remind you that even through the component correction, the '04/'05 cycle, on a rolling four-quarter basis our electronics marketing operating margins were holding fairly steady, while our TS margins were continuing to expand.

And in the current inventory correction that's going on, we have yet to see a contraction in operating profit margin. So the new paradigm might be up, sideways and then up some more, whereas the old paradigm was up, down, up, down.

Moving on, Harley mentioned this, I'd like to mention it again except that the Avnet Inc. [inaudible], I am very proud of our global leadership team. Most of the folks who are in my direct-report staff are 20-year proven performers within the distribution industry and within Avnet in specific, and we intend to leverage that stability to create further strategic advantage.

And the last thing I'd like to say about Avnet in specific is that we have this balance of our business between electronics marketing and technology solutions, and then within the two groups this diversified portfolio of suppliers and customers. So we offer you these financial metrics in a relatively low data environment.

I'm just going to close by saying that you know the macroenvironment that we operate in, coupled with Avnet's strategy and Avnet's execution, has brought us into this value creation era. We really believe that it's here. It's happening now and our results over the last couple of years have proved it. And you saw our Vision Statement, it hasn't changed for many years and it says that we are committed to delivering value to you our investors.

So we are intensely focused on the notion of shareholder value creation and we believe, by the way, as a result of that, we'll get TSR if we can build economic profitability the total shareholder returns will come eventually, even if we're trading at 10 times forward right?

So on behalf of our Board of Directors, on behalf of the presenters today and the balance of our executive team, on behalf of all the employees of Avnet, I thank you for being here today and thank you for your interest in Avnet. Vince do we have time for questions?

VINCE KEENAN: Well I think what we'll do is we'll take a few questions, I know some of you have got to go. If you want to grab a lunch on your way out, please feel free, and happy holidays to everyone. Take care.

urn:contentItem:5TC1-SRH1-JB4M-V397-00000-00A wakeup call for Europe2018-09-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:00ZLexisNexisA wakeup call for EuropeNicolas Berggruen;Nathan Gardels

Nicolas Berggruen is chairman of the Berggruen Institute and publisher of The WorldPost. Nathan Gardels is the editor in chief of The WorldPost.

PARIS - In the 1950s, French President Charles de Gaulle understood that if France wanted to create its own space for sovereign action in a world dominated by the United states and the Soviet Union, it had to possess its own nuclear force. Today, in the emerging global order dominated by the United States and China, artificial intelligence has become the most powerful resource that will determine the fate of nations in the times ahead. The only chance for not just France but Europe as a whole to remain a player is to participate fully in the development of AI.

The robust competition between America and China is accelerating the rapid evolution of machine learning, which will transform all aspects of life from employment and the social contract to genetic engineering and warfare. The pace of change is so swift that being left behind will make it nearly impossible to catch up. If that happens, Europe will become irretrievably subordinated to the geopolitical algorithms of others.

A new book by AI technologist and entrepreneur Kai-Fu Lee, "AI Superpowers: China, Silicon Valley and the New World Order," ought to serve as a loud wakeup call for Europe. Not surprisingly, Europe warrants little ink in Lee's book. As Lee sees it, while Silicon Valley and China are driving each other forward in the advance of AI, with an entrepreneurial frenzy abetted by abundant capital and a densely connected consumer base, Europe lacks a comparable innovation ecosystem or integrated digital marketplace. Its default alternative has been simply to accept the full platforms of the likes of Google, Facebook and Twitter. In essence, Europe has become a colony in the American tech empire.

Because emergent technologies arise in response to social demand, Lee does, however, see an opening for Europe. While AI development in China and the United States is driven primarily by the quest for data and analytics that can be used commercially, Europeans are focused more on protecting the privacy of the user. As Lee told us in an interview: "That will cause the American giants some amount of trouble and may give local European entrepreneurs the chance to build something that is more consumer and individual-centric and that would go further than American companies would ever contemplate in protecting privacy."

Europe's leaders should seize this opportunity by fostering a continent-wide collaboration to put its distinct stamp on AI. The most promising prospect for Europe would be to blaze a different path than the United States or China. It could put its resources behind the proposal of Tim Berners-Lee, inventor of the World Wide Web, to "re-decentralize" the Internet, both to assure a fairer allocation of the digital dividend and hand back control of personal data from big tech to individuals.

This culture-bound constraint on data collection, in turn, would reorient the development of AI in a more social instead of consumer-marketing direction, which has been the main focus of both China and Silicon Valley. Europe could further choose to compete where it has an advantage in basic science. Just as Europe joined together to create the Large Hadron Collider, the world's largest particle accelerator, European nations could cooperate on a project to be the first to build super-intelligent machines, ones that surpass human capacities.

The potential is there. The Scandinavian countries, of course, have long been engaged in the fray with such innovations as Skype and Spotify. Germany has its own digital modernization strategy, "Industry 4.0," aimed at upgrading its manufacturing base through machine-learning tools. And though not gaining much traction so far, Chancellor Angela Merkel has highlighted the importance of European Union investment in AI. She has even mused that Europe could present a third way for AI.

France, a core nation of Europe alongside Germany, can make a critical contribution. As the most active modernizer on the European scene today, French President Emmanuel Macron is well positioned to promote Europe's role as a third pillar of the AI revolution. Like de Gaulle in his time, Macron has an intuitive sense of what it takes to stay in the game - and a bold political imagination to figure out how to do so. From his first days in office, he has focused on invigorating Europe's entrepreneurial culture and bolstering state support for innovation, especially in AI.

"My goal is to recreate a European sovereignty in AI," he said. "If you want to manage your own choice of society, your choice of civilization, you have to be able to be an acting part of this AI revolution." Drawing on his country's heritage as a cradle of scientific discovery and the Enlightenment, he has recruited the brainy mathematician and AI guru Cédric Villani to lay the foundation for France's effort.

Macron is on the right track. The AI challenge may be just the summons a continent torn apart by persistent centrifugal forces - financial crisis, immigration and populism - needs to embrace unity more fully. An ambitious historic project aimed at reaping the economic benefits of AI, securing an independent presence for European values in the new world order and leading a scientific breakthrough to superintelligence would provide a binding narrative for a continent adrift. Such a moonshot vision would be far more compelling for Europeans than the tired pitch from Brussels that dourly sells a common Europe as canned spinach, something the paternal authorities say is good for you but that everyone hates.

Belatedly grasping what is at stake, E.U. regulators are now taking rearguard action against American big tech through the General Data Protection Regulation and other means. But if Europe wants to get ahead of the game, to recover the sovereign ability to chart its own course, it needs an innovation ecosystem that makes it the author of its own algorithms while at the same time building on its unique strengths in science.
