urn:contentItem:5YYK-CTG1-JCBW-N4DC-00000-00AWORLD WITHOUT LIMITS;Opportunities are emerging in the wake of coronavirus for those who are brave enough to take them. Megan Boxallkicks offour new series - The New Future - looking at how the world can be put back together and made better after Covid-192020-05-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:00ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 22,23,24,25AWORLD WITHOUT LIMITSOpportunities are emerging in the wake of coronavirus for those who are brave enough to take them. Megan Boxallkicks offour new series - The New Future - looking at how the world can be put back together and made better after Covid-19

There is an odd tranquillity about the coronavirus crisis. Quiet roads, empty skies and family bike rides have replaced the constant pounding of 21st century life. Where complaints about politics and policy, boredom and balance are overridden by an incomparable gratitude for good health. But it's an uneasy tranquillity. One that is disrupted with every death announcement, technological malfunction or glimpse of a shuttered shop which some fear may never reopen.

On an individual level coronavirus is having catastrophic consequences that stretch beyond the immediate health issues. In Britain, the fallout from lockdown is filtering through the economy, starting with the retail, hospitality and leisure industries and rippling up the property and banking sectors. Unemployment is rising and threatens to explode when the government's unfathomably expensive furlough scheme is inevitably lifted. Public sector employees - among them those who are providing life-saving services at the peak of the pandemic - will pay for the spending splurge with salary freezes in the years ahead.

But just as Captain Tom battled personal challenges to walk 1,000 laps of his garden (and in doing so warmed the hearts of a nation), there are plenty of encouraging stories of fortitude in business: gyms that have gathered new members by offering online classes; restaurants offering delivery services for the first time; a return in demand for local corner shops; and the farm that made more money in April 2020 by loaning its goats for entertainment in online conference calls than it did in April 2019 when it merely offered traditional farm visits.

Covid-19 has magnified weakness and exposed opportunities. That is why this crisis could be the first since the second world war with the potential for 'creative destruction' - the term used by economist Joseph Schumpeter in the 1940s to describe innovation as a means of ripping up the status quo to make way for something better.

Schumpeter used Henry Ford's moving assembly line - which resulted in a dramatic reduction in the cost of manufactured goods and laid the path towards modern consumer culture - as an example of entrepreneurship at its finest. Creative destruction has since been used to describe any innovation that paves the way for a better way of operating: Amazon (US:AMZN) and automated warehouses, for example; Netflix (US:NFLX) and the shift to content streaming; 3D printers and their potential to render global supply chains worthless.

It is true that destruction doesn't necessarily give way to creativity and innovation. On too many occasions, policymakers and corporations have failed to constructively rebuild when weaknesses have been exposed by trauma. But sometimes trauma (such as that caused by a major pandemic) provides a muchneeded catalyst for innovation.

Coronavirus has exposed gaping holes that need to be repaired. Applying the same sticking plasters used time and again to fix new wounds won't work. To build a better world in the wake of the destruction left by coronavirus, we need a change in thinking.

Economics from history Starting with the economy. Government responses to the Covid-19 pandemic have been monumental. The fiscal measures (government spending and tax cuts) to help businesses and families passed by US Congress will cost $2.2 trillion (£1.81 trillion). Finance ministers from the European Union approved a half-trillion-euro fiscal package, bringing economic support by the EU and member states to (EURO)3.2 trillion (£2.87 trillion) in aggregate.

When announcing the UK government's £330bnworth of support for businesses, Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak noted it was an intervention unprecedented in peacetime. The eventual cost to the UK government of all measures, including its furlough scheme to pay workers put on leave, is still to become clear. In 2020 alone, the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) estimates government borrowing could be £177bn - more than treble the estimate before the crisis.

Questions are now, rightly, being asked about the source of all this capital and how long it will take to pay back. In the UK, the extraordinary spending is a worrying reminder of the 2008 financial crisis, when the government borrowed heavily and then attempted to stimulate the shattered economy by slicing interest rates and initiating a quantitative easing programme. True, the banking sector was saved and is today arguably more stable than it was prior to the crisis, but the overriding outcome of the repair was 10 years of austerity and sluggish growth.

Once again, monetary and fiscal measures are not the answer to the country's economic challenges. Central bank base rates were already so low before the pandemic that further cuts aren't expected to provide much stimulus. Quantitative easing is also not the solution when demand has fallen just as rapidly as supply - there is no point in making it easy for people to spend their money if they are in lockdown. Meanwhile, austerity might succeed in bringing down the national debt, but it won't help stimulate growth.

There is also an individual economic fallout to consider. Base rate cuts and quantitative easing won't help the millions of workers who are facing job losses as the companies they work for scramble to save cash, or the private business owners who have had to close for good. Talk of V-shaped or U-shaped economic recovery is futile if continued austerity stunts consumer spending and cannibalises growth for another decade. Ministers can learn a lot from the UK's post-war economic boom. In the late 1940s Britain's debt to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio peaked at over 230 per cent. But rather than clamp down on spending, investment increased in the post-war years, catalysed by the formation of the welfare state and the National Health Service (NHS). And as government spending as a percentage of GDP rose steadily, national economic growth went with it. The same was true in the US where the benefits of President Roosevelt's 'New Deal' helped drag the country out of the Great Depression.

Perhaps the most obvious examples of post-war economic creative destruction come from Germany and Japan - two countries severely shaken by the fallout of war. Without the burden of policymakers or lobbyists, entrepreneurship and innovation thrived, leading to two of the strongest industrial economies of the post-war world.

The Green New Deal But innovative industrialisation isn't the answer to the economic concerns of the 21st century. Today, economists are troubled by uncontrollable population growth, resource competition and their role in exacerbating inequality and damaging the environment. It has taken a global pandemic and strict lockdown measures to reveal just how fragile the global economic system is. The threat of repeated virus outbreaks in a world where frequent international travel has become the norm raises questions about the role of globalisation and international supply chains.

The response, argues economist Joseph Stiglitz, should be greater investment in green initiatives that not only help rebuild, but "transform the economy into the 21st century kind of economy that we need". Mr Stiglitz is a strong advocate of a Green New Deal, which aims to address the issues of climate change and inequality to help stimulate the US economy, just as Roosevelt's New Deal did after the War. Closer to home, climate ministers from several member countries (now including France and Germany) are calling for the EU-wide stimulus packages to emphasise the transition to clean energy in a post-coronavirus world.

But perhaps policy is not as crucial in the war on climate change as we once thought. The rapid mobilisation against the coronavirus certainly raises questions about the lethargy in action against rising global temperatures, which the World Health Organisation links to an estimated 150,000 deaths per year. If governments are willing to leave themselves further indebted to the tune of hundreds of billions of dollars, in what amounts to a war effort against Covid-19, why has the possibility of a climate Armageddon been met so meekly by comparison? The difference is summarised by EDHEC-Risk Institute finance professor Riccardo Rebonata: "Covid-19 is a very 'clear and present danger', and this creates a dynamic of strong and ready political acceptance, very different from a 'slow-burning' problem such as climate change." Urgency, therefore, rather than policy is crucial to shifting the trajectory of global temperatures. Research from the London School of Economics argues that we should be moving away from the narrative of hardship and disaster that has dominated climate talks for several decades and instead focus on innovation, growth and investment opportunities. Emphasis of the universal benefits of green initiatives beyond climate impacts could also help shift behaviour: reduction in emission of air pollutants to improve respiratory health, more green space in cities and better walking and cycling routes for fun and commuting. Coronavirus has highlighted that we can exist in a world that is more carbon friendly. Sure, we're not going to be maintaining all the same behaviours that we have during lockdown, but demand for travel, especially for work, could reduce significantly in the 'new future'. Global populations might be more open to new work and travel solutions in the post-coronavirus world. The opportunities for innovation in the war on climate change is arguably more exciting than it has ever been.

And recent co-operation between governments and companies in the war on coronavirus is encouraging in terms of what is possible. The social impact finance team at legal firm Reed Smith notes how the likes of home appliance maker Dyson and the Mercedes Formula One team have helped design and manufacture ventilators to treat Covid-19 patients. Diageo (DGE) has used its expertise in alcohol to increase supply of antiviral hand wash. Burberry (BRBY) has been producing gowns for nurses and doctors. This collaboration could set a precedent for dealing with climate change.

Viruses can spread west It's not just the health of the planet that has been thrown into sharper focus by the coronavirus. Human health has unsurprisingly become a central concern as, for the first time in over a century, the western world faces a brand new medical threat.

That's not to say that pandemics are a new concept. Indeed, epidemiologists have been warning that international travel and global supply chains have threatened to facilitate the spread of an infectious disease for many decades. We have also had plenty of warning - swine and bird flu hit western shores in the mid-2000s, and the catastrophic consequences of Ebola in western Africa in 2014 captured global attention. The question is therefore pressing: why were we not better prepared? Perhaps the containment measures of recent virus outbreaks lulled western populations into a false sense of security. Accusations of unnecessary panic in the wake of swine flu and bird flu might explain why government responses in both the UK and US were delayed and confused. Control and containment measures have often felt sudden and reactive rather than carefully planned. Poor availability of personal protective equipment (PPE) and ventilators for hospitals has revealed how reliant some western healthcare systems are on global supply. Coronavirus has offered those systems an opportunity to reassess their operations. One thing is clear, rainy day preparations need a complete rethink.

It's no accident that some of the best responses to Covid-19 have come from countries in Southeast Asia, where the Sars and Mers outbreaks are a recent and painful memory. Local populations were quick to heed their governments' warnings about hygiene and social distancing. Testing and tracking - the two measures the British government is scrambling to put in place - were already in use in regions such as Hong Kong and Singapore and have helped to control infection and death rate. And that has added a new dimension to the argument about use of personal data.

The changing face of big tech When 2020 started, the biggest cloud hanging over the US tech sector was potential regulation. Alphabet (US:GOOGL) executives were expected to spend most of the year answering questions about how it uses people's data (in the same way Mark Zuckerberg did in 2019). Amazon was being hammered for monopolising industries and consumers were worried about Alexa listening to conversations. Social media sites were being criticised for using individual data to make money and failing to clamp down on the spread of misinformation.

Much has changed in a few short months. We're now talking about Google's increasing role in education, Amazon delivering vaccines, Microsoft (US:MSFT) and Apple (US:AAPL) tracking the spread of coronavirus around the world. Meanwhile, these companies aren't taking a penny from embattled governments. Their cash position means they can give freebies to struggling customers and money to help the coronavirus effort. In a crisis, cash-rich, data experts are the type of companies we want. The pandemic therefore offers an opportunity to reset how we think about technology and the responsible use of data.

Personal, anonymised data tracking is currently being used predominantly by advertisers, but its potential use stretches far beyond its current capacity. Data will help us reopen economies faster in the wake of coronavirus, keep tabs on future surges, and help distribute PPE and ventilators better. It is true that we need to be very careful about putting our data in the hands of a few conglomerates,. But rather than regulate it, perhaps we should be spending money protecting it - better telecoms networks which don't rely on Chinese state-funded companies and government-funded cyber security could ease the concerns surrounding company data use.

The response of big US tech companies during the coronavirus has also added a new dimension to the debate around monopolistic powers. Amazon, Alphabet, Apple and Microsoft have all faced regulatory pressure in the past few years for their dominant roles in their respective industries. But no one is complaining about how those dominant roles have allowed them to generate such lofty profits that they are able to support us all in times of catastrophe. Meanwhile, companies across many tightly regulated industries, including telecoms and airlines, have relied on taxpayer-funded support to help them through coronavirus and the subsequent economic fallout.

Schumpeter argued that monopolies were a way of emboldening innovation. Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet provide clear evidence of that. All three have monopolised their own industries and the retail, software and advertising markets respectively have provided them with extraordinary profits. Those profits have in turn been ploughed into innovation. Amazon, Alphabet and Microsoft are therefore going toe-to-toe in some of the most creative areas of technology - cloud computing and artificial intelligence, for example. Their profits have allowed them to compete fiercely for a breakthrough in 'the next big thing'. Thus, in the wake of coronavirus perhaps we should all be focusing on the new rather than desperately trying to protect the old. The breadth of industries that could benefit from creative destruction is reflective of the scale of the damage caused by coronavirus and the number of industries whose imperfections have been magnified by a major trauma.

The world that is waiting for us on the other side of coronavirus could be very different to the one we have left. But that doesn't have to be a bad thing.

'Economists are troubled by uncontrollable population growth, resource competition and their role in exacerbating inequality and damaging the environment'

Green investing is about more than just a fuzzy feeling

In the past few years, a hunt for altruism in a market that seemed to be on a never-ending mission upwards has sparked a rise in demand for

ethical investing. Companies are being given scores which reveal how well their environmental, social and governance (ESG) principles align with United Nations goals. Fund managers, ratings agencies and index providers have packaged up these companies into new products for investors. Sceptics have often called it a marketing method for a period of strong market growth.

But although there are undoubtedly limits to what ESG investing can achieve, its principles could provide the basis for a real shift in the way we think about investing. For example, bad ESG scores have the potential to force up the cost of long-term borrowing on bond markets and will reduce the price a company can issue new shares for on the equity markets (which means it costs the company a greater share of its business to raise the same sum of money). If the cost of capital is increasing because a company is recognised to cause externalities that hurt the

environment and society, then it has a real incentive to improve. During the Covid-19 pandemic, companies that score well on ESG have tended to suffer less badly in the dips. Research by the Bank of America noted that the top fifth of S&P 500 stocks by ESG score had by 25 March outperformed their peers in 2020 by 5 per cent. Going forwards, many of the old companies with less sustainable business models in terms of their environmental and social impact, are facing further challenges thanks to the legacy the coronavirus and measures to

combat it will leave. The companies with better ESG scores won't be immune to some of the same problems, but they are less likely to be weighed down by increases to their cost of capital. By investing in such businesses, investors can help reduce the cost of funding for companies that play a positive role in society and the struggle against climate change. Combined with

a proactive role by government and lessons on public-private partnerships learned fighting Covid-19, doing good for your portfolio can also help save the planet. JN

Covid-19 and the response to it has left a trail of destruction. Lives have been lost or permanently altered. Economies are bruised, job losses have soared and public sector deficits are set to serve as an unpleasant reminder of the trauma for many years to come. Many are now asking what comes next, and whether life will ever be quite the same again. ; ; But from the rubble of the destruction, opportunities are emerging to rebuild economies, industries and systems with new and innovative ways of thinking, as has been done so repeatedly in the past: towns that rebuild better after earthquakes, or Japan and Germany's thriving post-war economies, or business innovations such as Henry Ford's assembly line or Microsoft's Windows operating system. ; ; In exposing many of the weaknesses in the world's healthcare, economic and financial systems, the virus has offered both the opportunity to build back better and a roadmap for how we may do that. Companies and countries with the nerve to take those chances and create a new and improved future are likely to be well rewarded. Destruction can clear the path to innovation. ; ; In a new series of fortnightly features, we will be looking on a sector-by-sector basis - from healthcare to financial services - at how investors can navigate this simultaneously exciting and disruptive change that the world needs. ; ; Welcome to The New Future. ; ;

Axios Hosts Webinar On Broadband

August 27, 2020 12:30 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

FIL INC. FOUNDER FRANK LUNTZ

MICROSOFT PRESIDENT BRAD SMITH

REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CALIF.), MINORITY LEADER

AXIOS CO-FOUNDER MIKE ALLEN

[*]ALLEN: Welcome to this Axios virtual event. I'm Mike Allen, a co-founder of Axios. Welcome to my home in Arlington, Virginia. I'm looking out my window, the Key Bridge into Georgetown. This is the second of two events that we are doing of Microsoft on the future of employability during the Republican National Convention. We thank Microsoft for making these conversations possible and we thank you for taking a break during this busy newsy week to join us on Axios.com, to join us on Axios on Twitter with hashtag #axiosevents, on Facebook, and on YouTube.

Our first guest, Dr. Frank Luntz is someone whose advice is craved by corporations, candidates, and office holders on every continent. I've been to conferences, seminars, he's extremely popular. He's well known for his international bestseller Words that Work, Frank Luntz, thank you for joining Axios.

LUNTZ: Mike, it's an honor, it's a pleasure, and what we're going to talk about really does matter.

ALLEN: Well, thank you. Again getting the Axios lingo there. One this is one of the great serendipities. You and I were talking and it turned out you've done some real intense research on our exact topic today, which is the importance of broadband, the importance of tech and lifelong learning and one of the ways you think about it is getting people to think about the difference between a job and a career.

LUNTZ: We did a project, a major national project for working nation, and that organization is devoted, really focused on making a difference in teaching workers that they have to be skilled, they have to be trained for the careers of the future. And I think what makes working nation different is that it is completely nonpartisan, as is the issue.

Whether you're talking about broadband for young people to get them started on the information superhighway or you're talking about lifelong learning, which adults appreciate and are beginning to not only understand but embrace, that this is not a political issue. This is not a partisan issue and this is not based on income or education. That any worker at any time could lose their job because of automation or because of globalization or outsourcing and that you have to be prepared and that elected officials on the federal and state and local level have a responsibility to provide these programs so that people do and are able to make a difference in their lives.

And you mentioned the difference between job and career. And I don't know if you've got that statistic in front of you, but it's one of the great findings of the working nation survey. The idea that we think we have a job by 50 to 45 percent, but what we really want by 3 to 1 is a career. A job is something you go to from 9:00 to 5:00. A career is something you do 24/7. A job is something you're looking for the next one. A career is something that you love and embrace and you want to stay with it.

ALLEN: Frank, one thing that you've done is talk to people about the difference between the good life and the American dream. What's the distinction people make there and how does access to broadband, future education play into that?

LUNTZ: Well, it's one of the reasons why this conversation is so timely. The consequence of COVID-19 is that there's been so much job and career dislocation, that people are not working in the office anymore, that sampled some people who thought they'd be protected have not been. And to me, the importance is about planning. It's about knowing that you can't--it's knowing the unknown, as Donald Rumsfeld used to say.

And the working nation study is designed to help policymakers, designed to help businesses together, working together to ensure that we are prepared for any contingency so that young people have access to broadband so they can do their learnings, they can follow the lessons, they can read what they need to read and learn what they need to know to be competitive and to be prepared for college, career, and life and that working adults are prepared for any eventuality and that they actually embrace the future.

And I think that's important. This is not a challenge for today at the Republican convention. This is a challenge for evermore and it's with the Republicans, Democrats, independents, whether you live in a rural community or the most urban of communities. These are things that affect all of us.

ALLEN: Frank, your second slide looks at the fact that for those who don't have the right training, there could be so real serious unemployment based on outsourcing and automation. What's interesting is people really don't know who to blame, right? Just sort of walk us through your findings there.

LUNTZ: It's interesting to me that while globalization is one of the most discussed and polarizing issues and at both sides, both Republicans and Democrats try to turn it into an issue, what we learn from the working nation poll is that automation was a greater concern and outsourcing is number one. And we see this--we've become a global economy that there are some jobs and careers that aren't just simply easier to outsource, easier to fill in a global environment.

But that is no excuse for not getting the skills training, for not getting like long learning. And one of the--one of the aspects that is so essential is a politicians need to know the language that the public will respond to. And businesses need to provide those opportunities that the politicians and the government cannot do.

And Mike, I want to emphasize that this is not just an issue nationwide. Governors have a role to play. Mayors have a role to play. And in the end, individuals themselves have a responsibility to get the skills they need for the careers that they want.

ALLEN: Frank this is the most exciting part, the most interesting, juicy part. On this topic, what are the words that work and what are the words that bomb? How should companies, public officials, leaders be talking about this?

LUNTZ: Well, that's where the good life comes in. To a lot of people, the American dream is just that, a dream. But the good life has a different definition to it for some people. It's--it's a Sam Adams on the weekend. For other people, it's the right car or the right holiday. But what always matters is the idea that through systems like we have right now, through online training, through person to person skills providing, through conversations like you and I are having right now, that provides the basics for what we need to learn and what we want to know.

And the idea that lifelong learning beats every other phrase for describing what this process is and I'm eager that we teach young people that high school is just a step towards college or towards career training and once you graduate from college that's just a step towards the first job you have and once you have that job, that's just the stepping stone to the career that you want, that this is a seamless progression and that we realize that no matter what decade we're in, and I'm in my 50s, that I still have things to learn, I still have skills to enjoy, and that whatever job or career I have right now may be radically different than what I have in the future, but that's okay. In fact, I think we should embrace this it.

Working Nation is working with Republicans and Democrats working with the Congress, mayors, and governor is to ensure that we have a different mindset, and that's why I'm so grateful to be on this call that Microsoft sponsored because they are a great example of a company that is deeply involved in making the difference for their workforce so that they will be more successful for the long term.

ALLEN: And Frank, as we say goodbye, you've been going to the White House is more times than you could ever count, but at the end of the Republican National Convention, you're going to be there at the White House for President Trump's acceptance speech. What are you going to be listening for? What should we be watching for?

LUNTZ: Well you know, I'm a journalist in addition to being a practitioner and a pollster. And it was important to me that my Twitter followers embrace this. So I asked them yesterday 7500 interviews, more than 7500, 68 percent said go. Thirty-two percent say no. So I got on a plane last night. I'm here in Washington right now and I want to see if Donald Trump learns anything from Melania Trump's speech.

It was very highly regarded by the left and the right. CNN embraced what she had to say and how she said it because she showed heart. She expressed her condolences and her sympathies for those who have suffered with or even lost their lives because of COVID. We all know that Donald Trump is tough. The question is how big is his heart? And I'm going to be listening for whether he demonstrates empathy tonight rather than just strength tonight.

ALLEN: Frank Luntz, thank you for those words that work. Your Twitter feed at Frank Luntz is an awesome place to follow the convention. Frank Luntz, thank you for joining Axios.

LUNTZ: Mike Allen, it was an honor.

ALLEN: We'd like to thank Microsoft for making these conversations possible. Our next guest is Brad Smith, the president of Microsoft. He's the chief legal officer. He has an empire of 1400 people in 56 countries. He's a big ideas guy. Brad Smith, welcome to Axios.

SMITH: Well, thanks, Mike. Thanks for having me. It's great to be here.

ALLEN: Well Brad, it says you're in Redmond, Washington. You're supposed to be in Charlotte with me. Quite a change in the plans for the convention. And I know that you have been at many recent conventions and Microsoft and technology have really played quite a role for both party's conventions.

SMITH: Well, I think these conventions play such an important role in American politics. Really, they're part of our culture. They've been a fundamental part of our history, if you just think about what happened in Chicago in 1860 when the Republican Party surprised everyone by nominating Abraham Lincoln.

Over the last 20 years, technology has played a vital role. They made the conventions more accessible to the American public. They made so many of these things more interactive. That's why I was in Tampa in 2012 and Cleveland in 2016. We've been playing an important role in supporting the conventions. I had hoped to be in Charlotte this week.

ALLEN: So Brad, since I didn't have to travel, I had a little extra time so I curled up with a book. I curled up with this book. It's a great book. I recommend it. Tools and Weapons. This of course is Brad's book. And in there, you write about rural broadband. And Brad, you talk about rural broadband--broadband as the electricity of the 21st century. Do tell.

SMITH: Well first of all, I think it's right to think about broadband as the electricity of our age. If you want to use a telehealth service, you need broadband. If you want to take a Community College course online, you need broadband. If you're a small business and you want to grow and you want to create jobs, frankly, you've got to be in a place that has access to broadband. But in so many of our rural communities in the United States today, that is missing.

We have to close the broadband gap. It's why we are really passionate about it. Perhaps especially in the rural parts of our country because I think without this, we're just going to miss out on the opportunity to create the opportunities for people that they deserve.

ALLEN: And Brad, I think we have a picture of a truck showing some of the work that's being done in the field, showing some of the ways that the technology is being pioneered. Tell us about this fancy truck.

SMITH: Well, this captures a visit to one of our favorite places. Carol Ann Browne, my coauthor and I, we both work at Microsoft and this is in Ferry County in Northeastern Washington State. It's like a number of really beautiful parts of the United States. It is more rural. There is no broadband, or there was I should say there was no broadband until Microsoft worked with partners.

And specifically, that truck, I think it sort of reflects the best of American ingenuity. We provided a grant, but the person who put that truck together is one of the three County commissioners in Ferry County. And he used it to drive her around and literally test whether he could get a good connection with the TV white spaces technology that we have been helping to advance. This is basically wireless technology that uses terrestrial television, that part of the spectrum.

So just remember, for everybody who grew up with sort of a TV antenna or rabbit ears, you could get a good signal. Well, now we can use unused parts of that spectrum for broadband and we partnered with another company. They've created now a device that is sort of the receiver. You just put it on the side of your house and it can connect with an antenna that's 10 or 15 miles away. You then bring a cable into your house and you have Wi-Fi at broadband speeds.

This is what rural America needs either with this kind of technology or some other. It's actually I just think a fundamental importance to put the entire country on a level playing field in terms of real economic growth.

ALLEN: Yeah, you can see how that would be life changing especially I think of a family with young kids. I think we also might have a shot inside the truck just to give a little sense of what happens inside there.

SMITH: Yeah, this was great. I had the opportunity to learn first-hand. Look, this also reflects I think the best of almost America and do it yourself electronic engineering because what you see there is a Windows laptop and you know it is amazing what, you know, people with a little bit of financial support can go accomplish when you give them the ability to be creative. And that's what's happening in Ferry County, that is what is happening increasingly in rural counties across the country.

ALLEN: And Brad, some people had talked about COVID as sort of an X Ray on our society. You are way ahead on this issue, but I think we realize now with so much remote learning what a massive life changing imperative broadband becomes.

SMITH: I think that's very true. I mean, look, right now you actually can't go to school virtually in an effective way if you don't have access to broadband and you don't have a good computing device. There will obviously come a day when this pandemic will be behind us when kids will be back in class, in school buildings.

But even when that happens, there is a huge homework gap that we need to close and we need to live in a country where every student can access all the resources needed to do research, to do homework, to collaborate with other people. So even post-COVID, I think the importance of the broadband gap is not going to abate one bit. It will remain just as important to our future as it is right now.

ALLEN: By the way, Brad, you said two of the most beautiful words in the English language, two words I haven't heard in quite a while, and that is post-COVID. We've got a hope, right?

SMITH: Well look, I think this is a time not to think not only about what we need to do now but what we want to do next. And what we should be doing is not just rebuilding, but re-imagining the kind of country in which we want to live. The day will come when this is behind us. None of us knows for certain when the day will arrive, but the sooner we start envisioning what we want to build, the more we can harness the free market, call on small businesses, give them what they need to succeed. I think the better off we're going to be as a nation.

ALLEN: So Brad, you're not in Charlotte, but you have an exciting project going on there. You have a smart city initiative going on in Charlotte. And one of the big investments intentions of this investment was to help close the digital divide.

SMITH: Yeah, Charlotte is an important city for Microsoft. North Carolina is an important state for us as a company because we have thousands of employees who work in Charlotte, they support people across The United States. We invested last year more than $20 million to expand our presence in Charlotte. We--we're adding over 200 new employees and part of what we want to do is not just grow our employee presence, but really strengthen our commitment to the city and the state.

And you know, what we're doing in North Carolina is a part of what we're doing across the country. Specifically, we are bringing free digital learning opportunities to people. People, perhaps especially, who are looking either to find a new job who may have lost their job, or just wanted to progress in their own career.

So we've combined access to free resources online, low-cost tests and certifications so people can show employers what they've mastered. One of my favorite things through LinkedIn, which Microsoft owns is we created, you know, new courses. So if somebody wants to sort of get better about interviewing for a job through a PC they can take a course on sort of tips on how to do a better job of interviewing and then we even have artificial intelligence that will give people feedback about how they did so people can practice and learn. And I think that's just, you know, one example of how we can put digital technology to work to frankly help people succeed in the current environment and add to the digital skills there likely should need to be successful in the decade ahead.

ALLEN: Brad, I'm getting the hook here, but real quick, I wanted to squeeze this in. As I read about the Charlotte project, what I was most excited about was smart transit. Can you just give us one sense about smart transit?

SMITH: Well, when you think about it, we live in a world where data can help us with almost everything we do. It can promise you know, called cities, manage their transportation infrastructure, it can help individuals do a better job of avoiding traffic jams, at least in the days when people are driving more again and going back to the office, you know, just if you think about what it means to have a smart city. You know, we're all going to want, what we're going to see in the coming decade is a transportation infrastructure that is guided by data and I think especially for the public sector to build and maintain a transportation network. This can be a game changer.

ALLEN: And Brad, as we say goodbye at the end of our newsletter can we always like to have one fun thing, end on a lighter note and not many of us had had a guest off of airplane lately? You had an actual guest who got off an actual plane.

SMITH: Well, I was really fortunate. My father came to visit in the Seattle area this past weekend. It was great to have a guest in the house. He lives in southeastern Wisconsin. Yeah, we're all having to be very careful and, you know, be very safe, but at the same time, I think my father, my family, like so many American families we're yearning for a little bit of that normalcy that defined our lives before the year 2020 began.

ALLEN: Brad, for those who care about the Internet and society and technology, we all do, your Twitter feed is great. It's Brad Smith. And I should mention that your LinkedIn is also Brad Smith. And so Brad Smith of Microsoft, thank you very much for a great conversation.

SMITH: Sure. B-R-A-D-S-M-I. I look forward to connecting with people. Thank you as always, Mike.

ALLEN: Thank you for joining Axios. And now, batting cleanup, the House Republican Leader, Kevin McCarthy is a California. He's very wired into the Silicon Valley community. He is a tech early adopter himself. He's the real deal. Native Bakersfieldian, fourth generation from Kern County. Grandson of a cattle rancher, some of environment, and as if he doesn't have enough titles already, for in this week, he is chairman of the Republican National Convention. Mr. Leader, Mr. Chairman, welcome to Axios.

MCCARTHY: Thank you so much for having me. Glad to be back.

ALLEN: So does it being chairman give you some great perks?

MCCARTHY: You know, you've got to work and do a lot, but I did get it one big part. I got this big gavel, so I like that. I got a little gift.

ALLEN: And that's Reagan behind you, right?

MCCARTHY: That's Reagan behind me and then some pictures of my family. I love Reagan. You know if you ever wondered what this--the painting of Reagan is in color and he's smiling because if Reagan would tell conservatives anything, to be a happy conservative. If you believe your policies bring people more freedom and liberty, don't be angry about it. Be happy about it. And I think that's coming forward in this convention this week. It's been very good.

ALLEN: That's good advice for all of us. I mentioned you're an early adopter. And early on in this pandemic, you ordered a couple of dozen fitness trackers. You found an innovative use for them. Do tell. Do show.

MCCARTHY: Well, it is called a Whoop. Whoop.com. It's a company, a wearable. But what I found with this, it measures your sleep, it measures everything about your body. But you can tell by your respiratory, the changing of your respiratory rate, and that's an early indication of COVID. Even a couple days earlier than showing any symptoms.

I wanted to get it for all my staff, but the Congress denied me that, so I got it for all my campaign. So they--the way to say hey, if your respiratory rate moves two points, don't come into work that day. Stay home. And it's a way that we can stay safer together. We are wearing masks and others, but how can we have any early indication of it? And this is one of the wearables that you can do. PGA is actually--

ALLEN: As we think about--

MCCARTHY: --Yeah.

ALLEN: As we think about the way that the pandemic has changed our life, you have an opinion piece in the Financial Times talking about some of the real risk that the pandemic has exposed in America, a danger of this over dependence on foreign supply. There are some things the government can do, tax incentives. What do you think business should do to help close that gap?

MCCARTHY: Well you know when I was in business school getting my MBA, we'd always study Malcolm Baldwin, Just in Time, right? You want more efficiency and everything. But now we have to rethink that. How dependent have we become on China? And with China lying to the world and hoarding the PPE, what about the critical minerals like we don't make penicillin, we don't make vitamins anymore. What about a national stockpile? I think we should rethink a stockpile.

In the past, we would buy product and store hit in some government facility thinking you're going to send it out. By the time you ever need it. It's expired, it's been there 20 years. Let's think differently. What if we go to business? And let's take an example. Say 3M makes a million masks a year. Why don't we pay them to make 1.2 million masks, they store it and then the next year they result those masks and they put new fresh ones in?

So there's--in the world today, they can ship anything within 24 hours, so give the businesses an incentive to have it. And if you're already in China producing items, don't move to Vietnam. You should move to North America.

The one thing I've learned from this pandemic and what we're going through, you can still track things backwards--back and forth. And there are critical minerals and critical items that it's too important to sit back. And I'm a free marketer, but I don't want to be dependent on anybody else, especially when it comes to America.

So there are things we need to rethink to make sure we still have control here. And we are doing that when it comes to the vaccine and therapeutics, but you have to be able to make them in America and get those essential items here. Never again should we be dependent on some other country and those critical items that we need for our own health and security.

ALLEN: And one of the big factors that you point to in this overdependence is China and we've seen what China has done in Hong Kong. How worried are you about what China is going to be doing with Taiwan?

MCCARTHY: I'm very scared about this. It's not something because of COVID. Remember, 30 years ago you watched a million kids go to Tiananmen Square. They build the goddess of democracy that looked like the Statue of Liberty across from the portrait of Mao and you watched what China did rolling the tanks. You watched that young man stand in front of the tank that was willing--we knew he was going to lose his life. We don't know who he is today because we know he's not alive but he was willing to give that up for the idea of freedom.

And when you think of America, we are more than a country, we are in idea. An idea that inspires people 30 years ago at Tiananmen Square, inspire people for millions in the last year in Hong Kong that would come out for crave the idea of freedom of speech or the shipyard workers in Poland more than 30 years ago or the individuals that tore down a wall that divided two Germanys. We are watching China use a crisis in the world that they created to expand their own beliefs.

We watched what they do in the South China Sea, we're watching what they're doing now with shooting missiles, we watch as they build islands, say they weren't going to weaponize them and they do. We watch what they had stolen from us in the past, the IP. Now watching the FBI tell us that they wanted to influence our election to actually elect Joe Biden.

So I think China should be a critical element of what this election is about, but I went a year ago to the speaker to ask that could we get a bipartisan committee together, same number of Republicans, same number of Democrats not just looking at IP theft, but could we have one American strategy for what we're doing for the next 100 years? Because China does.

You know, in China, if you want to fly somewhere, you may have the money, but they won't sell it to you simply because it's what you have said or family members have. They give you a social score and they're going to put that on everybody. The if the NBA won't stand up to them, what's going to happen in the future? So I think the one perspective--we need one plan as Americans on what we're going to do with China. And I think all the allies would join us based upon COVID.

ALLEN: I mentioned at the top that you have close relations with the Silicon Valley. An issue that you were early on you were concerned about censorship of conservatives. How do you think that the big tech companies are doing in trying to assuage the fears in Washington? Washington definitely has the Valley in its sights. What's the advice you're giving those companies?

MCCARTHY: They're doing worse than they were before. They were letting politics run yet instead of the fairness of the business. They now have Democrats and Republicans very concerned. Their power is only getting larger. And in the world of COVID, it's getting larger because they have more influence.

But I don't think they were forthcoming in a lot. I have real concerns of what Google has been doing and I think you're going to hit a point--I've warned them time and again, you're going to hit a point where people are going to say you're a monopoly. If 90 percent of every search on the Internet goes through Google and you can control what people see and what people say and you want to influence an election, I don't think you're going to be able to maintain. If you're on the second page of Google and 90 percent of it drops off, that you've got a real problem.

If you're directing was it driving to sites and others, you're going to have a problem and people are going to think they're going to have to level the playing field. And I see a concern on both sides of the aisle. So I think they need to rethink what they're doing right now.

ALLEN: So it sounds like you strongly think that there is regulatory legal, legislative action coming big tech's way.

MCCARTHY: Yeah, and there's two different ways to handle this, which I disagree with what the Democrats want to do. They want to regulate it like it's that utility and then we get no innovation, nothing else. I want to have a competitive playing field, right? I mean, when you look at what Amazon is able to do--you know who should have been Amazon? Sears. They had the catalog, they sold you everything, but they failed. But competition proved something better.

What I see now from this big tech is there not allowing competition to come up. We see that time and again from their practices. That's where government really should come in because technology improves every single day. I mean, before Google, there was Yahoo and other search engines, right? And government came in and actually allowed Google to move up but now Google goes out and kind of quashes many times that we found any new small company from rising up. That's the place that we should really look at and to make sure there is a level playing field, there's competition that somebody is not controlling the market but utilizing it too control what people see and what people think.

ALLEN: And so just to put a bow on this, you're saying that Washington is more concerned about the tech companies than they were a year ago?

MCCARTHY: Well, yeah. Tech companies control more every single day. Think about it. From Instagram, from Google, from a search, from YouTube, from Facebook, those sound like four big companies. No, those are only two companies but they're controlling so much of our life and so much of what we see and know.

And in a world of COVID, you're relying on technology more because you're not going out. That's concerning to me and everybody else. And in the influence of what they're trying to do to make people on what you say, their determining now what free speech is. I haven't seen them ban China on what China does, but they want to ban what Americans think or say in a--in a free speech world. I think they're overstepping their bounds. I watched that time and again with Twitter.

ALLEN: All right, Mr. Leader, as we say goodbye, I'm going to ask you a question about human nature and I'm going to give you an example. So my nephew Morgan works at a coffee bar and he says that when you put a coffee in someone's hand, they don't even have to drink it, they're suddenly friendlier. They're nicer. It's purely psychological. At age 21, you started your first business. Kevin O's Deli. Tell me something you learned about human nature there that serves you as you campaign for House candidates, House members this fall.

MCCARTHY: It will be very interesting. You know, I won--I won the lottery, I invested, I took that money and opened a deli. I took a risk, right? Well, there are three lessons I learned. You're the first to work, last to leave, last to be paid.

You're going to listen more because it's the customer. You're going to find ways to constantly improve every single day. But in the business of service, you connect with somebody, right? They trust you because they are providing their hard work money to purchase something from you. They want to make sure the quality is at that higher level. They want to make sure you surpass expectations and you want to be able to take them almost to a different place, have them try something in a sandwich.

Some of my sandwiches are still around in other delis in Bakersfield today. They call it the McCarthy. It was Turkey, cream cheese, and artichoke hearts. Something that I never had ever made before and it wasn't something that I knew would be good, I just wanted it to try something new and expand somebody's taste. But they asked for something. I showed up on time, I made the quality better, and I made a connection with them that they knew my name. I put my name on the business, Kevin O's, so if they had a complaint, they knew who to come to.

That bill, that trust, the respect that you have for one another has never left me. And the most important part, you're willing to serve somebody. I still go back today and I work behind the counter and other businesses because I think the ability to serve somebody, regardless of their wealth, regardless of the color of skin or gender says something about the character of who you are.

ALLEN: Mr. Leader, Mr. Chairman, we look forward to your speech tonight and thank you for joining Axios.

MCCARTHY: All right. It's over.

(LAUGHTER)

ALLEN: Touche. We are adjourned. Thank all of you for joining the series. Thank Microsoft for these conversations about the future of employability. We appreciate your joining us in the two part series and huge shout out to the Axios events team. Incredible two weeks back to back of conventions programming that they pulled off. Most grateful to them. So thank--Microsoft, thank you all and look forward to seeing you on Axios.com.

Good morning. Heads-up: Every quarter Axios journalists highlight the trends they are watching in politics, energy, science, technology, business and more. As a subscriber to this newsletter, you'll see that in your inbox from Mike Allen tomorrow. The topic: "A brewing storm for big tech." Today's word count is a mere 712 words, or <3 minutes. What the White House billed yesterday as a high-profile counterpunch to "Medicare for All" turned out to be much less significant — a fairly normal, fairly vague policy statement with no real implications for 2020. Between the lines: Trump is promoting Medicare Advantage over traditional Medicare, and that does matter for the program and the federal budget. But it's not a new position, and not one that has much to do with the broader debate over the American health care system. What they're saying: "Proposals like 'Medicare for All,' as well as the public options, are not just impractical, they are morally wrong because they would demote American seniors to little better than second-class status," Medicare and Medicaid administrator Seema Verma told reporters yesterday. Reality check: Plenty of what the Trump administration has said is hyperbole, untrue or unknowable. And the policy the administration rolled out has little to do with these big-picture issues. "I think this is the shapings of a political argument for why 'Medicare for All' is bad, not an alternative to 'Medicare for All,'" said a health insurance executive familiar with GOP politics. Details: Yesterday's executive order requires regulatory changes advantageous to Medicare Advantage, which is run by private insurers. "This is not any radical change by the administration, just a continuation of their push to increase flexibilities in MA and increase the supplemental benefits offerings for beneficiaries," said Avalere's Chris Sloan. Go deeper: The hospital industry isn't just consolidating among . Deals are happening frequently at the local level, too, Axios' Bob Herman reports. Why it matters: Smaller hospital deals are just as important as large system mergers because local market power is paramount in health care — people usually get care close to where they live. A combined entity reduces competition, which could give it the upper hand in negotiations with commercial health insurers in its area. The big picture: The number of hospital mergers and acquisitions in the first half of this year tracked in line with 2018 and featured with , according to an analysis from . Plenty of smaller transactions are rolling out now, too. Between the lines: Hospitals contend their deals are about improving patient care. But their press releases and executives rarely, if ever, talk about the financial benefits of their new enhanced negotiating power. If hospitals in smaller communities combine, commercial insurers will have a harder time excluding any one of them from their networks, even if a hospital has poorer quality or higher prices. This is commonly called "all-or-none" contracting, and it's been cited in the . State and federal antitrust officials also have to investigate these kinds of regional deals, making it easier for those with antitrust issues to go forward. Bob has more . Go deeper: It's illegal for U.S. airlines to take off without a kit of lifesaving drugs on board, but the Federal Aviation Administration has been handing out exemptions because some of those drugs are facing shortages, the reports. Domestic and international flights must carry drugs for severe allergic reactions, cardiac arrest, irregular heart rhythm, slow heart rates and low blood sugar, Axios' Marisa Fernandez writes. In 2016 more than 50 airlines from the requirement to carry all 5 drugs in the medical kit, per NYT. Narrower exemptions are more common. Health officials are especially concerned about epinephrine or adrenaline, which can be life savers for the tens of millions of people with food allergies. Yes, but: Fainting, near-fainting and gastrointestinal problems are more common in flight than other emergencies, the Times reports. New York says it has reached a "milestone" in halting the measles outbreak that started in October 2018, and U.S. public health officials now believe the U.S. has retained its measles elimination status — just barely meeting the year deadline, a spokesperson for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Thursday. Yes, but: Recent cases reported from returning international travelers demonstrate the danger of new outbreaks when there are still pockets of communities with low vaccination rates, Axios' Eileen Drage O'Reilly . Despite measles being mostly preventable, the combination of the and places several communities at risk. Related: " Thousands of individual schools in the U.S. don't have high enough immunization levels to meet the threshold considered adequate to protect a population from measles," the Wall Street Journal . Wonder what it must be like to be the ER doctor who's in charge of making sure Bernie Sanders' heart is healthy (or being in charge of any presidential candidate's health, for that matter)? Some actual ER docs have wondered the same thing, Axios' Sam Baker writes.

The Ireland Department of Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation issued the following news release:

Axway, a market leader in governing the flow of data, has today [Wednesday] announced its commitment to the Irish economy by expanding its R&D Centre of Excellence based in Dublin. The move will immediately provide 15 software engineering jobs in the area and continue to grow over the years.

The Centre of Excellence will be Axway's global hub for its API Gateway research and development. APIs (Application Interface Programming) are the DNA of the next generational shift in technology; cloud, mobile, social and the Internet of Things will all be built using APIs. In our increasingly connected world, APIs break down the language barriers between multiple devices providing the foundations of the smart home and connected car.

Axway, on foot of its acquisition late last year of Irish company Vordel, is a world leader in the development of API Management technology. Axway, with 11,000 customers in more than 100 countries, is the only IT provider in the market today to manage, run, secure and monitor all business interactions across on-premises, Cloud, and Mobile. Each customer depends on Axway's proven breadth of services and layers of governance to build and improve value chain efficiency, regulatory compliance and quality of service.

The internet economy has often been credited with playing a key role in Ireland's economic recovery. Axway joins a list of other big tech firms such as Amazon, Facebook, Google and Linkedin, which have all recently expanded their operations in Dublin. The company expansion will look to make the most of the local engineering talent.

Welcoming the announcement Minister for Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation, Richard Bruton TD said "Axway's decision to expand its R&D Centre of Excellence and create 15 high quality jobs is a clear indication of Ireland's importance as a key location for technology companies to expand and grow their business. Under our Action Plan for Jobs we have identified the technology sector as an area of great potential and I am committed to ensuring that we continue to attract further investments and create much needed jobs for this economy".

"There is a world class software engineering population in Ireland and we want to recruit from this talent pool. Dublin in particular is globally acknowledged as a hub of engineering excellence and we will be looking to recruit senior engineering staff for our R&D Centre," said Laurent Bride, Executive Vice President of Research & Development, Axway." Engineers joining us will be working on some of the latest computing technologies as we evolve Axway's enterprise software portfolio, to ensure we are at the forefront of the Cloud and Mobile innovation curve".

Barry O'Leary, CEO, IDA Ireland said "Axway is a leading global provider of Software business solutions. Today's announcement further reinforces Ireland as the leading location for software companies like Axway to support and service customers in the EMEA region. I would like to offer Axway the continued support of IDA Ireland".

About Axwa

Axway (NYSE Euronext: AXW.PA), a market leader in governing the flow of data, is a global software company with more than 11,000 public- and private-sector customers in 100 countries. For more than a decade, Axway has empowered leading organisations around the world with proven solutions that help manage business-critical interactions through the exchange of data flowing across the enterprise, among B2B communities, cloud and mobile devices. Our award-winning solutions span business-to-business integration, managed file transfer, API and identity management, and email security- offered on premise and in the Cloud with professional and managed services.Axway is registered in France with headquarters in the United States and offices in 18 countries. www.axway.com

About Axway 5 Suite

Axway 5 Suite offers control and optimisation of the flow of data through integration, visibility, policy, security and reliability to govern business-to-business interactions, communities, systems and data types -- within and beyond the enterprise edge.

AXYS Morning Tea: MCB's stock's unexpected collapse

Mauritius ranks 10th 'least complex' in the TMF Group's Global Complexity Index stating "government has deliberately simplified legislation to make the jurisdiction more attractive". Speaking of accolades, Bank One earns a couple from Capital Finance International, and so does the amended Solidarity Levy. We also obtained some additional information on the 'Contribution Sociale Généralisée'. The Beach Authority's general manager resigns, while a Senior Lecturer at the University of Mauritius is convened to a disciplinary committee. Following the historic US ruling discrimination, the Mauritian LGBTQ community takes on our courts. Air Mauritius won't resume international service until August 31st. The Listed Companies Minority Shareholders' Association (LCMSA) writes to the President asking for an enquiry into both Air Mauritius and SBM Holdings. In copy were the Prime Minister, Members of Parliament, and the Press. Why not the regulators?  'Auto-Écoles' want to revert to pre-lockdown testing. Swimmers resume training. Hunting season is expected to yield 550t of venison. For all of you jackpot chasers, Saturday's will be Rs30M. It'll be an unusual 'streaming-based' Music day this Sunday.

India is elected to the UN Security Council as its border skirmish with China adds to its rising bilateral tensions with the EU, Australia and US. In coronavirus news, a new study based on excess deaths looks at its death toll while the World Health Organisation (WHO) ceases hydroxychloroquine trials. A group of 16 friends all contract Covid-19 during a night out in Florida. Oh! So NOW you get it? Ghana, whose economy grew by 4.9% during Q1, says African Americans are welcome back "Home". West African leaders explore a phased re-opening of borders. The Scandinavian isle leading the way in undoing carbon emissions. The UK's PM gets rear ended. Facebook will allow users to turn off political ads. Big Tech shows how to hold post-Covid conference. In sports news, the last stages of Champions League will be 'single-leg' affairs. Players took a knee and held a minute of silence for Covid-19 victims before kick-off. Anyone else found the 'crowd' voice over unnerving? Still better than eerie silence, wouldn't you say?

Asian business sentiment is at a record low according to this survey. HSBC resumes plan to slash 35k jobs. Saudi Aramco buys 70% of Saudi Basic Industries for $69bn. Tesla secures 6kt of Cobalt per year, a key component of Lithium Ion batteries, from DR Congo. The EU is drawing up shields against Chinese takeovers. Its anti-trust spree extends to PSA-Fiat with regards to 'lightweight commercial vehicles' (Think 'Renault Kangoo'). UK courts pave way for retailers to seek compensation from Visa and MasterCard. SouthWest has two years worth of cash! How about that? Although the Fed has reiterated its intent to apply all tools to aid the economy, Wallstreet ended lower. AsiaPac markets are following suit this morning. Will MCB Group bounce back from yesterday's late unexpected share price collapse? If so, will the current down-streak end?

With 3x as many drops as there were gains, it shouldn't come as a surprise that local indices retreated by up to 1%. The average gain stood at 1.2% against an average loss of 2.5%. The MCB Group's share price collapse to 3Wk-Low Rs230 (-3.0%) occurred during the final half-hour of trading amid an unexpected market sell-off. 80% of MCB Group Shares traded during this final half hour at VWAP Rs233.97 (-1.3%), against a VWAP of Rs237 (±0%) during the preceding four hours.

Turnover stood at Rs61M scattered among Terra Mauricia [22%], IBL [8%], Afrexim Bank [6%] who declared its annual dividend, Cim Financial Services [5%] and Ciel Ltd [5%]. SUN 6.50% 04-Nov-2023 bonds traded below par at a YTM of 8.26% (+187bps) on a foreign purchase, and made up 8% of today's turnover. LUX* Resorts (-4.0%) cooled-off. Investment companies were among the worst performers losing around 5%.

In Other Market News

African Export-Import Bank (Afrexim) declared an annual final dividend of $0.254 per depositary receipt (DR) up 0.8% than during its previous financial year on June 17th 2020. Afrexim will trade cum-Dividend up to July 1st with payment scheduled as from July 13th 2020.
